title: #InTheirWords
credits_intro:
This is a pivotal moment in history for the gay community in America. The Supreme Court’s decision ensures that states cannot deny same-sex couples the same marriage rights that heterosexual couples have enjoyed.

Prior to the decision, USA TODAY interviewed people within the gay community to hear #InTheirWords about how this decision will impact their lives and why they deserve marriage rights.
share_intro: YOUR TURN. CONTINUE THIS CONVERSATION BY SHARING THIS VIDEO.

videos.video_quotes: On her wedding: "I felt very privileged.”
videos.videodescription: Lena says she is emotional when she discusses her marriage to Candy, because it's a privilege that many gay and lesbian couples still do not have.
videos.sharelanguage: "People who’ve come before have been struggling and fighting.”
videos.intro: Meet Lena. She's a gay rights advocate with the Latino GLBT History Project.
videos.questionasked: Tell us about your wedding day.

videos.video_quotes: If the court upholds the bans: "I'll be heartbroken."
videos.videodescription: Lena says that if the Supreme Court upholds state bans against gay marriage she will be heartbroken.
videos.tags: Supreme Court decision, if state marriage bans are upheld
videos.sharelanguage: “As many stops as we encounter it only energizes us, encourages us."
videos.intro: Meet Lena. She's a gay rights advocate with the Latino GLBT History Project.
videos.questionasked: How will you feel if the Supreme Court upholds state bans on gay marriage?

videos.video_quotes: Lena's father upon learning she was pregnant: "Just know that I love you and support you."
videos.videodescription: Lena expected a battle when she told her family she was pregnant and married to a woman. Instead her dad told her he supported her.
videos.sharelanguage: A father's response to learning his gay daughter is pregnant.
videos.intro: Meet Lena. She's a gay rights advocate with the Latino GLBT History Project.
videos.questionasked: Have you ever had an experience where a friend or family member expressed that you should not get married?

videos.video_quotes: On discrimination: "I find myself hesitating when I say 'wife'."
videos.videodescription: Lena says she doesn't feel discriminated against openly, but there are times when she catches herself or thinks that she may make someone uncomfortable if she refers to Candy as her wife, rather than her partner.
videos.sharelanguage: On discrimination: "I find myself hesitating when I say 'wife'."
videos.intro: Meet Lena. She's a gay rights advocate with the Latino GLBT History Project.
videos.questionasked: Have you ever felt uncomfortable or discriminated against?

videos.video_quotes: “I don’t wake up wondering what heterosexuals are doing in their bedroom.”
videos.videodescription: Lena says that opponents of same-sex marriage seem to focus on what goes on in the bedroom rather than everyday life. She says her family is no different than a straight family -- they fight over bills, go to the movies and love each other.
videos.tags: family, sex, gay vs. straight families
videos.sharelanguage: “I don’t wake up wondering what heterosexuals are doing in their bedroom."
videos.intro: Meet Lena. She's a gay rights advocate with the Latino GLBT History Project.
videos.questionasked: What is something that people misunderstand about LGBT families?

videos.video_quotes: “Any parent wants their kid to come into a better world.”
videos.videodescription: Lena says that she hopes one day her child will not have to deal "with bullying or ridicule."
videos.tags: children, gay vs. straight families, two mothers
videos.sharelanguage: “Any parent wants their kid to come into a better world.”
videos.intro: Meet Lena. She's a gay rights advocate with the Latino GLBT History Project.
videos.questionasked: How do you think having parents of the same gender will impact your child?

videos.video_quotes: "Ya'll have two daddies? That's cool."
videos.videodescription: Kaleb and Kordale talk about helping out at their children's school and the kinds of questions kids ask about having two dads.
videos.tags: children, gay vs. straight families, two fathers
videos.sharelanguage: "Ya'll have two daddies? That's cool." @KordaleNKaleb
videos.intro: Meet Kaleb and Kordale. They are fathers with three kids living in Georgia.
videos.questionasked: How has having parents of the same gender impacted your kids?

videos.video_quotes: If the Supreme Court upholds the bans: "I'll be devastated."
videos.videodescription: Kaleb and Kordale say they'll be devastated if the state gay marriage bans are upheld by the Supreme Court. They live in Georiga and will not be able to get married.
videos.tags: if state marriage bans are upheld, children, discrimination
videos.sharelanguage: If the Supreme Court upholds the bans: "I'll be devastated." @KordaleNKaleb
videos.intro: Meet Kaleb and Kordale. They are fathers with three kids living in Georgia.
videos.questionasked: How will you feel if the Supreme Court upholds state bans on gay marriage?

videos.video_quotes: "People have a right to voice their own opinion in a respectful manner."
videos.videodescription: Kaleb and Kordale tell about a time they were harrassed in front of their children in a grocery store.
videos.sharelanguage: "People have a right to voice their own opinion in a respectful manner." @KordaleNKaleb
videos.intro: Meet Kaleb and Kordale. They are fathers with three kids living in Georgia.
videos.questionasked: Tell us about a time you felt discriminated against because of your sexual orientation.

videos.video_quotes: "People are starting to understand, 'Hey I don't do what they do, but they're still people.'"
videos.videodescription: Kaleb and Kordale talk about how being gay within the black community has changed over time.
videos.sharelanguage: "I don't do what they do, but they're still people." @KordaleNKaleb
videos.intro: Meet Kaleb and Kordale. They are fathers with three kids living in Georgia.
videos.questionasked: Have you seen progress in your lifetime as to how gay people are treated?

videos.video_quotes: "It's all about respect."
videos.videodescription: Kaleb and Kordale say people have the right to disagree with same-sex marriage, but they should be respectful.
videos.tags: discrimination, two fathers, gay vs. straight families
videos.sharelanguage: "It's all about respect." @KordaleNKaleb
videos.intro: Meet Kaleb and Kordale. They are fathers with three kids living in Georgia.
videos.questionasked: What do you wish people who are opposed to same sex-marriage understood?

videos.video_quotes: On same-sex marriage: "Why do I have to fight for this moment?"
videos.videodescription: Kaleb and Kordale say they want to get married for the same reasons heterosexual couples want to get married.
videos.sharelanguage: On same-sex marriage: "Why do I have to fight for this moment?" @KordaleNKaleb
videos.intro: Meet Kaleb and Kordale. They are fathers with three kids living in Georgia.
videos.questionasked: Why do you want to get married?

videos.video_quotes: “I would want to know ... my marriage is legal in that state.”
videos.videodescription: Austin and Aaron Rhodes say they think same sex-marriage should be a federal issue.
videos.sharelanguage: "I would want to know ... my marriage is legal in that state.” @AustinRhodes_ @AaronRhodes_“
videos.intro: Meet Austin and Aaron. The twins are YouTube stars.
videos.questionasked: Should gay marriage be a federal or state issue?

videos.video_quotes: "We've been trained that only a man and a woman should get married."
videos.videodescription: Austin and Aaron Rhodes say they struggled accepting their sexuality in part because they come from a very religious family. Aaron says the underlying message at church was always that a man and a woman were the only people who should be able to get married.
videos.sharelanguage: "We've been trained that only a man and a woman should get married." @AustinRhodes_ @AaronRhodes_
videos.intro: Meet Austin and Aaron. The twins are YouTube stars.
videos.questionasked: Have you felt discriminated against because of your sexual orientation?

videos.video_quotes: “It just comes back to love."
videos.videodescription: Austin and Aaron Rhodes say they believe that same-sex couples with children will become the new normal by the time they decide to have children.
videos.sharelanguage: On same-sex marriage: “It just comes back to love." @AustinRhodes_ @AaronRhodes_
videos.intro: Meet Austin and Aaron. The twins are YouTube stars.
videos.questionasked: What's the future like for same-sex couples with children?

videos.video_quotes: "(Coming out on YouTube) gave us a chance to really connect with people."
videos.videodescription: Austin and Aaron Rhodes talk about their decision to come out to their father in a YouTube video.
videos.sharelanguage: "(Coming out on YouTube) gave us a chance to really connect with people." @AustinRhodes_  @AaronRhodes_
videos.intro: Meet Austin and Aaron. The twins are YouTube stars.
videos.questionasked: Why did you decide to tell your father you were gay on YouTube?

videos.video_quotes: "Coming out is an act of love."
videos.videodescription: Allen Rose says coming out was difficult, but making the choice to share your true self with someone is an act of love.
videos.sharelanguage: "Coming out is an act of love."
videos.intro: Meet Allen. He advocates for LGBT Catholics.
videos.questionasked: How did you come out?

videos.video_quotes: "Our relationships are of the same value as straight people's relationships."
videos.videodescription: Allen Rose says the Supreme Court decision could equalize how gay and lesbian families and relationships are viewed by the public and local governments.
videos.tags: state vs. federal, Supreme Court decision, family
videos.sharelanguage: "Our relationships are of the same value as straight people's relationships."
videos.intro: Meet Allen. He advocates for LGBT Catholics.
videos.questionasked: How will the Supreme Court decision impact you?

videos.video_quotes: "We're not a gay couple, just a couple."
videos.videodescription: Allen Rose says real equality will be reached when he is seen as just a man, not a "gay man."
videos.sharelanguage: "We're not a gay couple, just a couple."
videos.intro: Meet Allen. He advocates for LGBT Catholics.
videos.questionasked: What does this moment in history mean to the gay community?

videos.video_quotes: "If the Supreme Court upholds the bans I would be really disappointed."
videos.videodescription: Allen Rose says he will be really disappointed if the Supreme Court upholds the state bans. However, he said it will create a new generation of activists.
videos.tags: if state marriage bans are upheld,  Supreme Court decision
videos.sharelanguage: "If the Supreme Court upholds the bans I would be really disappointed."
videos.intro: Meet Allen. He advocates for LGBT Catholics.
videos.questionasked: How will you feel if the Supreme Court upholds state bans on gay marriage?

videos.video_quotes: "Expanding rights for any group is better for all Americans."
videos.videodescription: Allen Rose talks about how he celebrated the Supreme Court's decision to strike down the Defense of Marriage Act.
videos.sharelanguage: "Expanding rights for any group is better for all Americans."
videos.intro: Meet Allen. He advocates for LGBT Catholics.
videos.questionasked: How will you feel if the Supreme Court does not uphold the state bans?

videos.video_quotes: "Catholics as a whole are very supportive of gay rights in general."
videos.videodescription: Allen Rose talks about being gay within the Catholic Church.
videos.sharelanguage: "Catholics as a whole are very supportive of gay rights in general."
videos.intro: Meet Allen. He advocates for LGBT Catholics.
videos.questionasked: Are Catholicisim and marriage equality at odds with one another?

videos.video_quotes: "I internalized that (homophobic) discrimination and felt it against myself."
videos.videodescription: Allen Rose says he expereinced internalized homophobia.
videos.sharelanguage: "I internalized that (homophobic) discrimination and felt it against myself."
videos.intro: Meet Allen. He advocates for LGBT Catholics.
videos.questionasked: Have you expereinced discrimination because of your sexual orientation?

videos.video_quotes: "The appropriate place for marriage equality is the federal government."
videos.videodescription: Allen Rose used to think that same-sex marriage was a state issue, but now he thinks it is a federal one.
videos.tags: Catholicism, discrimination, state vs. federal, religion
videos.sharelanguage: "The appropriate place for marriage equality is the federal government."
videos.intro: Meet Allen. He advocates for LGBT Catholics.
videos.questionasked: Should same-sex marriage be a state or federal issue?

videos.video_quotes: “We met in my first year of seminary.”
videos.videodescription: Holly and Kaci Clark-Porter talk about meeting each other and deciding to date when they attended seminary school.
videos.sharelanguage: The story of how @2Rad2bRev and @theimagodei fell in love at seminary.
videos.intro: Meet Holly and Kaci. They are married and ordained ministers.
videos.questionasked: How did you meet?

videos.video_quotes: "God calls us as queer people to be loving, to be in marriages."
videos.videodescription: Holly and Kaci talk about how the church has evolved and address criticism from people who feel like being Christians and gay may be at odds.
videos.sharelanguage: "God calls us as queer people to be loving, to be in marriages." @2Rad2bRev @theimagodei
videos.intro: Meet Holly and Kaci. They are married and ordained ministers.
videos.questionasked: How do you react to people who say that being Christian and LGBT are at odds?

videos.video_quotes: “(Some) churches are not only welcoming their queer members, they're celebrating their queer members."
videos.videodescription: Holly and Kaci talk about how churches' stance on the LGBT community has changed. Holly says progressive and conservative churches are increasingly polarized on marriage equality.
videos.sharelanguage: Churches are increasingly polarized about same-sex marriage @2Rad2bRev @theimagodei
videos.intro: Meet Holly and Kaci. They are married and ordained ministers.
videos.questionasked: How are churches changing in regard to LGBT people?

videos.video_quotes: “I dated amazing men. I married an amazing man. I just never felt at home with men.”
videos.videodescription: Holly and Kaci talk about coming out to their family and friends after meeting and falling in love at seminary school. Holly says her faith strengthened her resolve to do admit what she always knew — that she was a lesbian.
videos.sharelanguage: "I married an amazing man. I just never felt at home with men.” @2Rad2bRev @theimagodei
videos.intro: Meet Holly and Kaci. They are married and ordained ministers.
videos.questionasked: You were both married to men, can you tell me about coming out?

videos.video_quotes: "Hearts have been changed from a place of judgment and fear to a place of openness."
videos.videodescription: Kaci says that she feels like there are more proactive ways to insight change in people who do not agree with the LGBT community. She says instead of focusing on discrimination and the negative she focuses on change on a smaller scale.
videos.sharelanguage: "Hearts have been changed from a place of judgment and fear." @2Rad2bRev @theimagodei
videos.intro: Meet Holly and Kaci. They are married and ordained ministers.
videos.questionasked: Was there a time you felt discriminated against?

videos.video_quotes: "Sometimes I feel like half of our own country doesn’t want us there.”
videos.videodescription: Kaci talks about moving from a state where their marriage is not recognized to Delaware, where it is recognized. The couple talks about the effect the Supreme Court decision will have on LGBT couples.
videos.tags: Supreme Court decision, state vs. federal
videos.sharelanguage: "Sometimes I feel like half of our own country doesn’t want us there.” @2Rad2bRev @theimagodei
videos.intro: Meet Holly and Kaci. They are married and ordained ministers.
videos.questionasked: How will the Supreme Court decision affect you?

videos.video_quotes: On the political divide: "We must be the United States of America."
videos.videodescription: Holly says that she hopes there will be a federal decision on gay marriage. She wants the states to be “united” in accepting all citizens regardless of sexual orientation.
videos.tags: Supreme Court decision, state vs. federal, polarization
videos.sharelanguage: On the divide over gay marriage: "We must be the United States of America."@2Rad2bRev @theimagodei
videos.intro: Meet Holly and Kaci. They are married and ordained ministers.
videos.questionasked: Do you think same-sex marriage should be a state issue or a federal issue?

videos.video_quotes: On support from their community: "People have switched from being our opposition to being our allies."
videos.videodescription: Julie and Hillary tell stories about their neighbors and how they responded to the Goodridge v. Department of Public Health case.
videos.sharelanguage: "People have switched from being our opposition to being our allies."
videos.intro: Meet Julie and Hillary. They were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case for same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.
videos.questionasked: How did people respond to your decision to sue for marriage rights in Massachusetts?

videos.video_quotes: "(Divorce) gave us the framework to dismantle the relationship."
videos.videodescription: Julie and Hillary say divorce gave them the framework necessary to dismantle their marriage in a careful way.
videos.sharelanguage: "(Divorce) gave us the framework to dismantle the relationship."
videos.intro: Meet Julie and Hillary. They were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case for same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.
videos.questionasked: Tell us about your divorce.

videos.video_quotes: On same-sex marriage: "I think that most people in the country are ready."
videos.videodescription: Julie and Hillary say it will be sad if the Supreme Court upholds the bans because most people in the country are ready.
videos.tags: if state marriage bans are upheld, Supreme Court decision, goodridge plaintiffs
videos.sharelanguage: On same-sex marriage: "I think that most people in the country are ready."
videos.intro: Meet Julie and Hillary. They were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case for same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.
videos.questionasked: How will you feel if the Supreme Court upholds the state bans?

videos.video_quotes: "We wanted to be able to walk into the pediatricians office and not be questioned about which one of us was the real mother."
videos.videodescription: Julie and Hillary talk about why they decided to become the lead plaintiffs in the 2001 lawsuit against the Massachusetts Department of Public Health. They won the case in 2003 and were one of the first couples to marry.
videos.sharelanguage: "We wanted to ... not be questioned about which one of us was the real mother."
videos.intro: Meet Julie and Hillary. They were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case for same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.
videos.questionasked: Why did you join the Massachusetts lawsuit for marriage rights in 2001?

videos.video_quotes: "It's marriage. There's nothing different about it."
videos.videodescription: Julie and Hillary explain why they prefer the term "equal marriage" instead of "gay marriage."
videos.tags: equality, Supreme Court decision, labels, goodridge plaintiffs
videos.sharelanguage: Julie and Hillary Goodridge on same-sex marriage: "It's marriage. There's nothing different about it."
videos.intro: Meet Julie and Hillary. They were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case for same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.
videos.questionasked: Why do you prefer the term "equal marriage" instead of "gay marriage"?

videos.video_quotes: "Who doesn't love a wedding?"
videos.videodescription: Julie and Hillary talk about how they will feel if the Supreme Court does not uphold the state marriage bans.
videos.tags: if state marriage bans are upheld, Supreme Court decision, goodridge plaintiffs
videos.sharelanguage: On same-sex marriage rights: "Who doesn't love a wedding?"
videos.intro: Meet Julie and Hillary. They were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case for same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.
videos.questionasked: How will you feel if the Supreme Court decides not to uphold the state bans?

videos.video_quotes: On tax rules and marriage rights
videos.videodescription: Julie and Hillary talk about how the Supreme Court decision will impact their lives personally.
videos.tags: divorce, goodridge plaintiffs, Supreme Court decision
videos.sharelanguage: Julie and Hillary Goodridge talk about how the Supreme Court decision may impact them.
videos.intro: Meet Julie and Hillary. They were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case for same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.
videos.questionasked: How will the Supreme Court decison impact you personally?

videos.video_quotes: "Our wedding was a little bit of a media showcase."
videos.videodescription: Julie and Hillary talk about the day they got married.
videos.sharelanguage: Julie and Hillary Goodridge: "Our wedding was a little bit of a media showcase."
videos.intro: Meet Julie and Hillary. They were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case for same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.
videos.questionasked: Tell us about your wedding day.

videos.video_quotes: “It’s far easier to be a gay person in Republican circles than a Republican in gay circles.”
videos.videodescription: Gregory says many gay Republicans are actually more accepted in straight Republican circles than “coming out” as a Republican in their gay friend groups.He says Log Cabin Republicans stress that there is nothing wrong with being gay and nothing wrong with being a gay Republican.
videos.sharelanguage:
“It’s far easier to be a gay person in Republican circles than a Republican in gay circles.” 
 @gregorytangelo
videos.intro: Meet Gregory. He advocates for LGBT acceptance with the Log Cabin Republicans.
videos.questionasked: What is your experience being both Republican and gay?

videos.video_quotes: “Marriage equality is no threat to (Republicans) or their faith.”
videos.videodescription: Gregory says there is still work to be done within the Republican party. He says Log Cabin Republican is trying to help many understand that marriage equality is not an assault to their faith. He thinks the next battles will be non-discrimination protections for LGBT individuals to ensure that gay individuals can’t be fired based on their sexual orientation or identity.
videos.sharelanguage: “Marriage equality is no threat to (Republicans) or their faith.”@gregorytangelo
videos.intro: Meet Gregory. He advocates for LGBT acceptance with the Log Cabin Republicans.
videos.questionasked: What change would you like to see in the Republican party towards the LGBT community?

videos.video_quotes: “This is not a matter of policy but of individual respect for peoples lives.”
videos.videodescription: Gregory says he won’t be affected by the Supreme Court decision immediately, but it will have a great impact on Log Cabin Republican members who live in states where their marriage is not recognized.
videos.sharelanguage: “This is not a matter of policy but of individual respect for peoples lives.” @gregorytangelo
videos.intro: Meet Gregory. He advocates for LGBT acceptance with the Log Cabin Republicans.
videos.questionasked: How will the Supreme Court decision affect you?

videos.video_quotes: "We're not asking for anything more or anything less than full equality."
videos.videodescription: Gregory says he refers to it as marriage equality instead of same-sex marriage, because the LGBT community is not asking for anything but equal rights that heterosexual couples have had for years. He says same-sex marriage implies it’s something different or wrong.
videos.sharelanguage: "We're not asking for anything more or anything less than full equality." @gregorytangelo
videos.intro: Meet Gregory. He advocates for LGBT acceptance with the Log Cabin Republicans.
videos.questionasked: How does marriage equality differ from same-sex marriage?

videos.video_quotes: "There is a federal right to marriage equality."
videos.videodescription: Gregory says Log Cabin Republicans believe that under the Equal Protection clause, gay marriage should be a federal decision instead of by state. He says this will  ensure that LGBT couples have the same rights as heterosexual couples.
videos.tags: if state marriage bans are upheld, Supreme Court decision, Republicans, politics
videos.sharelanguage: "There is a federal right to marriage equality." @gregorytangelo
videos.intro: Meet Gregory. He advocates for LGBT acceptance with the Log Cabin Republicans.
videos.questionasked: Should gay marriage be a state or federal issue?

videos.video_quotes: “I did not come out to my parents, I was outed by my parents."
videos.videodescription: Gregory says there were years when his parents did not speak to him because of his sexual orientation. He says his conservative parents just recently accepted him.
videos.sharelanguage: “I did not come out to my parents, I was outed by my parents." @gregorytangelo
videos.intro: Meet Gregory. He advocates for LGBT acceptance with the Log Cabin Republicans.
videos.questionasked: Do you have family members who were not accepting of your sexual orienation?

videos.video_quotes: On coming out: "I've had to hide that part of my identity for so long."
videos.videodescription: Mala says she felt discriminated against during her whole childhood and young adult life.
videos.sharelanguage: On coming out: "I've had to hide that part of my identity for so long." @malaskumar
videos.intro: Meet Mala. She's an Indian-American novelist.
videos.questionasked: Was there a time you felt discriminated against?

videos.video_quotes: On south Asian parents: “Their parents didn’t get married because they were in love ...”
videos.videodescription: Mala says that the challenges facing the south Asian LGBT community are different than those facing gay and lesbians from other cutlural backgrounds.
videos.sharelanguage: America's same-sex marriage debate doesn't necessarily translate to arranged marriage. @malaskumar
videos.intro: Meet Mala. She's an Indian-American novelist.
videos.questionasked: What challenges are unique to gay individuals who are also south Asian?

videos.video_quotes: “Marriage is one of the things every country in the world...understands.”
videos.videodescription: Mala talks about what the Supreme Court decision on same-sex marriage will mean for her and others in the LGTB community.
videos.sharelanguage: “Marriage is one of the things every country in the world ... understands.” @malaskumar
videos.intro: Meet Mala. She's an Indian-American novelist.
videos.questionasked: How will the Supreme Court decision affect you?

videos.video_quotes: If the court upholds the bans: “It sets a precedent for inequality.”
videos.videodescription: Mala says that if the Supreme Court upholds the state marriage bans it will be disheartening for the LGBT community, because the court rarely hears cases and likely won’t revisit the issue for years.
videos.tags: Supreme Court decision, if state marriage bans are upheld
videos.sharelanguage: If the Supreme Court upholds state marriage bans: “It sets a precedent for inequality.”@malaskumar
videos.intro: Meet Mala. She's an Indian-American novelist.
videos.questionasked: How will you feel if the Supreme Court upholds the state bans?

videos.video_quotes: On why same-sex marriage is a federal issue.
videos.videodescription: Mala says that same-sex marriage is both a state and a federal issue.
videos.tags: state vs. federal, Supreme Court decision
videos.sharelanguage: On why same-sex marriage is a federal issue. @malaskumar
videos.intro: Meet Mala. She's an Indian-American novelist.
videos.questionasked: Should same-sex marriage be a state or federal issue?

videos.video_quotes: "Once we have same-sex federal marriage we will finally be on an equal playing field."
videos.videodescription: Mala says this moment will touch many Americans. She says that we currently have a “piece wise” system of gay marriage, where those who do not have the resources to live in a state where same-sex marriage is legal are at disadvantage.
videos.sharelanguage: "Once we have same-sex federal marriage we will finally be on an equal playing field." @malaskumar
videos.intro: Meet Mala. She's an Indian-American novelist.
videos.questionasked: What does this moment in history mean for the LGBT community?

project_credits: @mitchthorson @lagrisham @marybowerman @JessicaDurando @HollyTMoore @toryhargro Tim Loehrke Jack Gruber Darr Beiser @USATODAY

people.person_intro: Meet Holly and Kaci. They are married and ordained ministers.
people.person_bio: Rev. Kaci Clark-Porter and Rev. Holly Clark-Porter were jointly ordained at Delaware’s First and Central Presbyterian Church, where Kaci is an associate pastor. Holly is a minister at Big Gay Church, a community for LGBT Christians that meets once a month. They are from Texas and both women had prior marriages to men.
people.person_name: Rev. Holly Clark-Porter and Rev. Kaci Clark-Porter

people.person_intro: Meet Gregory. He advocates for LGBT acceptance with the Log Cabin Republicans.
people.person_bio: Gregory Angelo is the executive director of Log Cabin Republicans, an organization dedicated to furthering the political interests of the LGBT community. Angelo also serves as executive director of the Liberty Education Forum, a non-partisan think tank that advocates acceptance of the LGBT community. He lives in Washington, D.C.

people.person_intro: Meet Austin and Aaron. The twins are YouTube stars.
people.person_bio: Austin and Aaron Rhodes are twin brothers and models living in Los Angeles. The YouTube personalities came out to their father in a YouTube post video that went viral.

people.person_intro: Meet Lena. She's a gay rights activist with the Latino GLBT History Project.
people.person_bio: Lena Hernandez is a consultant in Washington, D.C. She previously worked as the special assistant to the president & CEO of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute. Hernandez was awarded the Latina Leadership Award by the Latino GLBT History Project for her advocacy work. She is expecting her first child with her wife, Candy, in August. The couple married in Virginia.

people.person_intro: Meet Kaleb and Kordale. They are fathers with three kids living in Georgia.
people.person_bio: Kaleb Anthony and Kordale Lewis are fathers raising three children together. The pair became Internet celebrities after a photo of them helping their daughters get ready for school went viral on Instagram. Their family was featured in a Nikon commercial for the company’s “I am generation image” campaign. Kordale published a book about their life together in 2014 called Picture Perfect. They live in Georgia and want to get married as soon as it's recognized in their state.

people.person_intro: Meet Mala. She's an Indian-American novelist.
people.person_bio: Mala Kumar is an Indian-American novelist with a background in international development. She quit her job at the United Nations because she did not feel the organization supported their LGBT employees. She wrote a column about her decision and published it on The Advocate website in 2014. She came out publicly in the piece with the closing line "I am gay." Her recently published novel, The Paths of Marriage, chronicles tension between a lesbian and her Indian-American family.

people.person_intro: Meet Allen. He's a practicing Catholic who is also gay.
people.person_bio: Allen Rose serves on the board of DignityUSA, a national organization founded in 1969 that champions LGBT Catholics. Rose advocates for the Catholic Church to accept the LGBT community and same-sex marriage legislation. He's engaged to be married this year in Washington, D.C.

people.person_intro: Meet Julie and Hillary. They were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case for same-sex marriage in Massachusetts.
people.person_bio: Julie and Hillary Goodridge were the lead plaintiffs in the landmark case Goodridge v. Department of Public Health. Massachusetts became the first state to legalize same-sex marriage when the state's Supreme Judicial Court ruled in their favor. The two married on May 17, 2004, and were one of the first same-sex couples to do so in the country. Though the couple divorced in 2009, they’ve remained friends and raised daughter Annie together.

tag_text: WHAT WOULD YOU LIKE TO HEAR ABOUT
project_share_text: LGBT voices on same-sex marriage and the upcoming Supreme Court decision
project_head:
THE SUPREME COURT DECISION THAT LEGALIZES SAME-SEX MARRIAGE ACROSS THE USA IS A MILESTONE IN THE COURT’S 226-YEAR HISTORY.

LISTEN AS GAY MEN AND WOMEN SHARE THEIR STORIES ABOUT WHY THEY DESERVE MARRIAGE RIGHTS.
